<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two blocks, A and B, are joined by a thin thread that passes over a frictionless pulley. Block A is at rest on a rough horizontal surface and block B is held at rest, just below the pulley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 455, 136]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the thread hanging loose.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 144, 809, 295]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 307, 591, 326]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
Block B is released and it falls vertically. The thread remains loose until block B has fallen a distance of \(0.45 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 376, 403]]<|/det|>
The mass of block B is \(0.50 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 146, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 920, 450]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<form>change in g.p.e. .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 571, 146, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 571, 401, 590]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 602, 920, 620]]<|/det|>
When the thread tightens, it pulls on block A which moves to the right at a speed of \(0.60 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 632, 853, 651]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 740, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<form>impulse = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 863, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

Fig. 3.1 shows her position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A quantity of gas is trapped by a piston in a cylinder with thin metal walls. The piston is free to move without friction within the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 437, 135]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the cylinder and piston.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 144, 787, 297]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 312, 532, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 344, 437, 361]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is placed inside a freezer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 375, 146, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
The air in the freezer is at atmospheric pressure, which is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). The area of the piston in contact with the air in the freezer is \(2.4 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 181, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 730, 440]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 497, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 529, 181, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 529, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
When the cylinder is first placed into the freezer, the temperature of the gas in the cylinder decreases and the air pushes the piston into the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 575, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
Calculate the work done on the piston by the air in the freezer as the air pushes the piston a distance of \(0.021 \text{m}\) into the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 668, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 148, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
The initial temperature of the cylinder and the gas is \(21^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) and, in the freezer, the temperature of the cylinder decreases to \(- 18^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 746, 544, 764]]<|/det|>
The thermal capacity of the cylinder is \(89 \text{J} /\text{°C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 777, 636, 796]]<|/det|>
Calculate the change in the internal energy of the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 885, 920, 904]]<|/det|>
<form>change in internal energy = ........................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
When the temperature reaches \(- 18^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), the pressure of the gas in the cylinder is still equal to that of the atmosphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the particles of the gas, how the pressure remains equal to its original value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 320, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 382]]<|/det|>
As the temperature of the metal cylinder decreases, the volume of the metal decreases. The decrease in the volume of the metal is much less than the decrease in the volume of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the particles of the metal, why the decrease in the volume of the metal is less than that of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 536, 90]]<|/det|>
Only one isotope of gold occurs naturally on Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
State what this indicates about the nuclear structure of all the naturally occurring atoms of gold on Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 210, 146, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 608, 229]]<|/det|>
There are several artificially produced isotopes of gold.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 908, 260]]<|/det|>
Gold-198 ( \(^{198}_{79}\mathrm{Au})\) is an artificial isotope which is used in medicine and in scientific research.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 725, 291]]<|/det|>
Gold-198 decays by \(\beta\) (beta)-emission to a stable isotope of mercury.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 870, 917, 905]]<|/det|>
To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer- related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge Assessment International Education Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 913, 917, 938]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of Cambridge Assessment. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is a department of the University of Cambridge.
